title: Question 119

children: A 92-year-old woman is being discharged home in the care of her daughter after treatment for heart failure. Medical history is also significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Outpatient medications are lisinopril, carvedilol, atorvastatin, and furosemide. She is currently asymptomatic. At the time of discharge, physical examination shows no evidence of volume overload and laboratory studies are normal.
Which of the following factors is fundamental to a successful transition of care for this patient?

text.__html: Discharge planning by the hospital physician
Explicit communication with the primary care physician

children: Poor communication between inpatient and outpatient clinicians and between providers and patients is associated with increased risk for hospital readmission.
A multidisciplinary team approach to discharge planning decreases the risk for readmission.
The factor in this patient's hospital discharge process that is fundamental to a successful transition of care is explicit communication with the primary care physician (

). Poor communication between inpatient and outpatient clinicians and between clinicians and patients is associated with increased risk for hospital readmission. During transitions, physicians should strive to provide clear, concise, and accurate patient records to subsequent clinicians. Physicians must additionally educate patients and families on the expected course and red flag symptoms that necessitate reevaluation.

A multidisciplinary team approach to discharge planning should decrease this patient's risk for readmission. Transitions of care are enhanced when multidisciplinary teams, including those with a dedicated case manager, are used for hospital discharge planning. Discharge planning by the hospital physician (
) is an important and necessary element of successful transitions of care but by itself is often not sufficient.

Accurate medication reconciliation, although time consuming, is paramount to decreasing the likelihood of readmission because medication errors frequently occur with transitions of care. Medication reconciliation during this patient's discharge process is a crucial factor in reducing the risk for subsequent readmission. This may be performed by the discharging clinician or pharmacist; several studies have shown that medication reconciliation is most effective when performed by a pharmacist. Medication reconciliation performed by the patient's daughter alone (
) misses the opportunity for best practices associated with reducing premature hospital readmission.
The simple ordering of laboratory tests is not fundamental to a successful transition of care. Laboratory tests may not be necessary in the immediate postdischarge period (
), particularly if predischarge laboratory values were normal.

objective.__html: Manage transition of care at hospital discharge.

references: Kamermayer AK, Leasure AR, Anderson L. The effectiveness of transitions-of-care interventions in reducing hospital readmissions and mortality: a systematic review. Dimens Crit Care Nurs. 2017;36:311-6.
